low.label: You're in a more cautious phase with dating confidence.
strengths: You don't rush into anyone just because you feel you should be dating.
You think carefully about how you show up and care about making a good impression.
growth: Start with tiny risks: reply, say yes to a short coffee, or start one new chat.
Treat awkward dates as normal practice, not proof that you are not good enough.

moderate.label: Your dating confidence is in a healthy, mid-range zone.
strengths: You can take initiative when a connection feels promising.
You usually recover from a bad or awkward date instead of quitting completely.
growth: Notice where you still hold back and push one step further, like suggesting a meetup or replying sooner.
Swap thoughts like 'I will be awkward' for 'It is okay if I am awkward, I am still worth meeting'.

strong.label: You have strong dating confidence.
strengths: You're willing to start conversations and suggest in-person plans.
You see rejection and awkward dates as part of the process, not a verdict on you.
growth: Keep your confidence tuned to the other person's pace and boundaries.
Focus on being real, not just performing well, so people see the honest you.

low.label: Right now, you lean more toward keeping your deeper emotions private in dating.
strengths: You're selective about who you open up to, which can protect you.
You can stay functional and keep going even when life is heavy.
growth: Try adding one more honest line, for example mentioning that this week has been stressful and why.
When you feel hurt, name it softly instead of only pulling away.

moderate.label: You're somewhat emotionally open, with room to deepen.
strengths: You share parts of your inner world once some trust is there.
You can talk about problems after you've had time to think.
growth: Experiment with sharing a bit earlier, not only when things feel serious.
Use simple feeling words such as 'I felt disappointed', 'I felt happy', or 'I felt nervous'.

strong.label: You're strongly emotionally available.
strengths: You can talk about feelings, stress, and needs in a clear, grounded way.
You're willing to bring up hurt or confusion instead of letting it pile up.
growth: Protect your own limits; you do not have to be available for deep talks all the time.
Notice if you overshare too fast to create instant closeness, and let trust build step by step.

low.label: You currently approach physical and sexual closeness quite cautiously.
strengths: You don't let anyone rush your pace into intimacy.
You often prioritize emotional safety over ticking boxes about how far you went.
growth: Define what feels okay for you, such as hugs, hand-holding, or cuddling, and say that clearly.
Use simple lines like 'Let's stay here for now' or 'Can we just cuddle tonight?'.

moderate.label: You have a moderate level of comfort with intimacy.
strengths: You can enjoy affection when you feel safe and respected.
You notice when something feels off and can adjust.
growth: Share more about what helps you feel relaxed and connected, not just what you do not want.
Be a bit more proactive in saying what you like and when you want to slow down.

strong.label: You're generally comfortable with physical and sexual intimacy.
strengths: You can be present and enjoy physical closeness when it feels right.
You're fairly tuned in to your body's signals and needs.
growth: Check that your physical pace also matches your emotional readiness.
Keep checking in with the other person's comfort, not only your own.

low.label: You're still finding your voice around physical and sexual boundaries.
strengths: You care deeply about other people's feelings.
You're very sensitive to the other person's mood and reactions.
growth: Practice short boundary lines like 'Let's stop here' or 'I don't want to do more tonight'.
Remind yourself that your comfort and consent matter just as much as theirs.

moderate.label: You sometimes hold your boundaries, but it's still hard in some moments.
strengths: You can say no or slow down when something clearly doesn't feel right.
You try to balance your needs with the other person's desires.
growth: Watch the grey-zone moments where you go along just to keep the peace.
Prepare one or two go-to phrases so speaking up feels easier in the moment.

strong.label: You're strong at setting and communicating boundaries.
strengths: You can say no, slow down, or change course when you're not comfortable.
You can discuss differences in desire or pace and look for a fair middle ground.
growth: Make sure clear boundaries do not turn into rigid rules; stay open to discussion.
If you feel guilty after saying no, remind yourself that you are allowed to protect your comfort and safety.
